page.title: 20ARMED FORCES
page.content: But for the action of the War Department towards the end of the last century in acquiring a large slice of shingle running along the coast from Jury's Gap to south of Lydd in Kent, Camber and Dungeness might by now have been linked by a strip of bungalows. As it is Camber's entity is protected to the west by the Rye golf course and the river Rother and to the east by the Lydd gun ranges part of which fall within the parish boundary. Behind a high wire fence which bounds the Jury's Gap_Lydd road, British and NATO troops carry out training on a recently updated complex of target areas. Fortunately for the peace and quiet of the Camber residents the sort of heavy artillery which tried out lyddite on the ranges in earlier days is no longer deployed there. All firing is directed out to sea.
